evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and consistently observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew remains the most plausible explanation despite alternative hypotheses, as no evidence contradicts its presence or impact during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features such as misaligned task execution, delayed information sharing, and unclear role responsibilities observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal data.

slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and criteria defined for deficiencies in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and consistently observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: The statements from crew members accurately reflect their communication behavior and observations.
No other unreported communication occurred that could have mitigated the breakdown.
defeaters: If evidence showed active, clear, and effective communication among crew members during the pushback phase.
If the crew had explicitly coordinated and confirmed actions to prevent the collision.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly indicates a lack of communication and coordination among the crew during the pushback, as the tug instructor did not receive warnings from the wingman or headset operator (H8), the trainee driver did not voice concerns (H10), and the headset operator assumed the instructor's actions without questioning (H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: The evidence does not provide detailed transcripts or recordings of communications, so some ambiguity remains about the full extent and timing of communication attempts.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure was present and observable in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal data.

defeaters: Evidence of any mechanical or control system malfunction or failure during the event
Maintenance or technical reports indicating mechanical/control failure
Witness statements describing mechanical/control failure
outcome.reasoning_summary: None of the provided history evidence items (H1-H13) mention or describe any mechanical or control failure being present or observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the pushback or related operations.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not present or not visible at the time of inspection
If the aircraft or personnel were not at the specified location during the inspection

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The presence and observability of the TRP environmental marking at the specified location and time is directly supported by H7 and H13, confirming the marking existed and was known to personnel.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The history evidence (H4, H6) documents the procedural deviation and resulting damage, while H8 and H12 describe the operational context and communication issues, confirming the deviation is recorded and accessible in operational records.
outcome.uncertainty_source: The evidence is from history notes without explicit mention of formal documentation or record accessibility

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features such as misaligned task execution, delayed information sharing, and unclear role responsibilities observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal data.

assumptions: Assuming that the lack of warnings and assumptions indicate communication/coordination breakdown
Assuming that the described behaviors reflect misaligned task execution and unclear role responsibilities
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and role clarity preventing the incident
If the crew had explicit procedures followed that contradict the breakdown claim

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly shows misaligned task execution (instructor continuing past TRP), delayed or absent information sharing (no warnings from wingman or headset operator), and unclear role responsibilities (assumptions made by crew members without communication) as per H8, H10, and H12.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in the extent of role clarity and communication protocols; no explicit procedural documentation provided
